assistants.name: Clinical Guidelines Agent
assistants.description: Specialized healthcare assistant grounded in CDC and WHO guidelines.
assistants.systemPrompt: You are a specialized medical AI assistant. ONLY answer based on clinical guidelines from CDC and WHO. Be precise and cite guidelines if necessary.

messages.content: Can you provide a comprehensive example of markdown rendering?

Certainly! Here is a demonstration of various **Markdown elements** rendered in the chat UI.

### Formatting Elements

1.  **Bold Text**: Essential for emphasis.
2.  *Italic Text*: Used for subtle highlights.
3.  ~~Strikethrough~~: Marking out dated information.
4.  `Inline Code`: Perfect for referencing variables like `user_id`.

### Data Presentation

Here is a table showing standard vs mock data:

| Feature | Standard Request | Rendered Result |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| Routing | Static Pages | Dynamic (`/chat/[id]`) |
| Renderer | Raw String | `react-markdown` |
| Data | Hardcoded | `dummy-db.json` |

### Blockquotes & Code Blocks

> Blockquotes are great for citing clinical literature or emphasizing a specific ruling.

Here's an example of a JSON code block:

```json
{
  "status": 200,
  "message": "Markdown rendered successfully!"
}
```

Feel free to interact with these elements or let me know if you need to see other styles like [hyperlinks to external resources](https://example.com)!
Enumerate WHO infertility guideline components and specify which section addresses male diagnostic protocols

The WHO ‚ÄúGuideline for the prevention, diagnosis and treatment of infertility‚Äù is organized around three primary components ‚Äî prevention, diagnosis and treatment „Äê0](9789240115774-eng.pdf)„Äë.  In addition, the guideline contains a later chapter that discusses research gaps and future updates (Chapter 12) „Äê1](9789240115774-eng.pdf)„Äë.  

The documents that were retrieved do not specify which particular subsection or chapter of the guideline is devoted to male‚Äëspecific diagnostic protocols, so that detail cannot be provided from the available sources.

documents.text: Guideline for the prevention, diagnosis and treatment of infertility

1. Infertility prevalence estimates: 1990-2021. Geneva: World Health Organization; 2023 (https://apps.who.int/iris/handle/10665/366700). 2. The selection and use of essential medicines 2023: web annex A: World Health Organization model list of essential medicines: 23rd list (2023). Geneva: World Health Organization; 2023 (https://iris.who.int/handle/10665/371090). 3. The selection and use of essential in vitro diagnostics: report of the fourth meeting of the WHO Strategic Advisory Group of Experts on In Vitro Diagnostics, 2022 (including the fourth WHO model list of essential in vitro diagnostics). Geneva: World Health Organization; 2023 (https://iris.who.int/handle/10665/373322). 4. Mburu G, Kiarie J, Allotey P. Towards a nuanced view and response to global fertility trends. Lancet. 2024;403(10440):1953-56 ( https://doi. org/10.1016/s0140-6736(24)00490-2). <!-- image --> ## Chapter ## 12 Research gaps, future scope and updating the guideline

23. Misell LM, Holochwost D, Boban D, Santi N, Shefi S, Hellerstein MK et al. A stable isotopemass spectrometric method for measuring human spermatogenesis kinetics in vivo. J Urol. 2006;175(1):242-6 (https://doi.org/10.1016/S00225347(05)00053-4). 24. Kimmins S, Anderson RA, Barratt CLR, Behre HM, Catford SR, De Jonge CJ et al. Frequency, morbidity and equity - the case for increased research on male fertility. Nat Rev Urol. 2024;21(2):102-24 (https://doi.org/10.1038/ s41585-023-00820-4). 25. Cates W, Farley TM, Rowe PJ. Worldwide patterns of infertility: is Africa different? Lancet. 1985;2(8455):596-8 (https://doi.org/10.1016/ s0140-6736(85)90594-x). 26. Honig SC, Lipshultz LI, Jarow J. Significant medical pathology uncovered by a comprehensive male infertility evaluation. Fertil Steril. 1994;62(5):1028-34 (https://doi.org/10.1016/ S0015-0282(16)57069-1).

messages.content: Can you summarize the infection control measures?

Various guidelines cover infection control extensively. Standard precautions apply to all patient care, and transmission-based precautions (Contact, Droplet, and Airborne) are added based on suspected infections „Äê0](cdc-ic-standard.pdf)„Äë. Hand hygiene is consistently highlighted as the most critical measure „Äê1](who-hand-hygiene.pdf)„Äë. Additionally, appropriate use of PPE is required when exposure to infectious material is anticipated „Äê2](ppe-guidelines.pdf)„Äë. Environmental cleaning and disinfection also play a huge role in preventing healthcare-associated infections „Äê3](env-cleaning.pdf)„Äë. Facilities must implement proper respiratory hygiene protocols „Äê4](resp-hygiene.pdf)„Äë and manage sharps safely to prevent occupational exposures „Äê5](sharps-safety.pdf)„Äë.

documents.text: Standard Precautions are the minimum infection prevention practices that apply to all patient care, regardless of suspected or confirmed infection status of the patient, in any setting where health care is delivered.
Hand hygiene is a core element of patient safety for the prevention of health care-associated infections and the spread of antimicrobial resistance.
Personal protective equipment (PPE) refers to wearable equipment that is designed to protect health care personnel from exposure to or contact with infectious agents.
Routine cleaning and disinfection of environmental surfaces are essential to reduce the risk of transmission of healthcare-associated pathogens.
Respiratory hygiene/cough etiquette infection prevention measures are designed to limit the transmission of respiratory pathogens spread by droplet or airborne routes.
Safe handling and disposal of needles and other sharp objects are critical to preventing healthcare worker exposure to bloodborne pathogens.

messages.content: What about specifically for airborne transmission?

For airborne transmission, such as with tuberculosis or measles, airborne precautions must be implemented in addition to standard precautions. This primarily involves placing the patient in an Airborne Infection Isolation Room (AIIR) „Äê0](cdc-airborne-iso.pdf)„Äë and requiring healthcare personnel to wear a fit-tested NIOSH-approved N95 or higher-level respirator before entering the room „Äê1](osha-resp-protect.pdf)„Äë. Restricting the movement of the patient outside the room is also advised unless absolutely necessary, in which case the patient should wear a surgical mask „Äê2](who-patient-transport.pdf)„Äë.

documents.text: Airborne Infection Isolation Rooms (AIIRs) are single-patient rooms at negative pressure relative to the surrounding areas, and with a minimum of 6 air changes per hour.
Employers must implement a written respiratory protection program with required worksite-specific procedures and elements for required respirator use.
When transport of a patient on Airborne Precautions is necessary, place a medical mask on the patient, if tolerated, to contain infectious droplets.
